messageBody:
On Fri, 25 Apr 2003 12:24:58 +0100, "Jonathan Oddy"
<j.oddy@...> said:
> This message only has an HTML part -- this is a text generated
> representation
>
>
> I understand that in general we want to write tests and test cases
> that are
> not dependent upon each other so that an earlier failing(?) test
> doesn't set
> state of the underlying object(s) to prejudice later tests. Okay
> fine, but
> I was wondering how people solve/resolve the following type of
> dependency.
> If I have three classes A, B and C where A delegates some
> functionality to B
> which delegates to C. During my implementation and unit testing I
> write
> tests for C then implement the desired functionality in C. I then
> repeat
> the process for B and A, okay fine. But now I have an implied unit
> test
> dependency don't I? So when running my tests as a suite I really want
> my
> test cases to run in the order C, B, A and never any other order
> because if
> the defect is in C then I want to know about it from C and not from A
> or B.
Seeing the error in A or B shouldn't preclude seeing the error in C. If
it does, you need to strengthen your test cases for C. I find this to be
a good problem. The tests for A and B become more than unit tests, they
become 'sand box' tests as well (testing how well objects play together).
If you don't like this behavior and you are able to separate the
functionality, you could resort to simply testing the new unit level
functionality of B and A and not concerning yourself with the delegated
functionality.

Then again, if neither of these appeal to you or are possible, you could
use Vladimir's JUnit-Addons to order your test cases.
